New Records: Boston Celtics set a single-game franchise record and tied the all-time NBA high with 29 made threes in a 132-109 victory over the New York Knicks.
Key Match Events: Jayson Tatum went 8-for-11 on threes as part of a superb 37-point, 10-assist performance.
Derrick White and Jaylen Brown were 6-of-10 and 5-of-9, finishing with 24 and 23 points, respectively.
Collectively, the Celtics’ starting five went 26-for-41 on 3-pointers (63.4%).
The Knicks’ starters were 4-for-17, and they finished 11-for-30 as a team.
Pre-Game Insights: The Celtics took head coach Joe Mazzulla’s preference for threes over twos to a new extreme as they began their title defense.

The Knicks made a pair of bold offseason moves aimed at challenging the Celtics for Eastern Conference supremacy, including trading five first-round draft picks for Mikal Bridges to beef up their wing defense.
Post-Match Reflections: Josh Hart of the Knicks commented on the Celtics' performance, saying 'The NBA needs to drug test all of them, because that was — I ain’t never seen nothing like that before, man.'

Knicks head coach Tom Thibodeau reflected on the game, stating 'Mathematically, it’s going to be hard to win that game. Twenty-nine threes made, (61) they took. We shot a high enough percentage (36.7%), but the 3-point game, mathematically, you’re not winning that.'

Josh Hart also mentioned, 'They’re already an explosive team, and obviously there was energy in the arena today that was contagious. They played extremely well. We’ll look at it, we’ll learn from it. Look at some of the defensive missteps that we had that led to their shots. But it was Game 1. There’s (81) other ones. We’re not going to overreact.'
